newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Tax authorities raid Murdoch subsidiary in Israel.
newsitem.headline: Tax authorities raid Murdoch subsidiary in Israel.

text.p: Israeli tax authorities said on Sunday they had raided the offices of a company controlled by media magnate Rupert Murdoch and removed documents, but denied media reports of any arrests.
News Datacom Research Ltd, a Jerusalem-based company controlled by Murdoch's UK-based News Corp, forcefully denied any wrongdoing.
"It is correct that we are directing an investigation against News Datacom Research," said Sarit Giladi-Dor, a spokeswoman for the Income Tax Authority.
She said investigators had also raided the offices of News Datacom's attorneys and auditors but would not confirm their names.
Giladi-Dor said further details could not be released until the investigation was formally declared public.
She denied Israel Radio reports that the authority had petitioned the Jerusalem District Court to detain Murdoch if he were to enter Israel or that there had been any arrests.
Israel Radio said authorities were investigating suspicions that News Datacom had failed to pay as much as 500 million shekels ($163 million) in taxes and royalties owed the Israeli government.

The radio said authorities believed the company had failed to pay full income tax or royalties due the government in exchange for research and development assistance. Giladi-Dor declined comment on the report.
News Datacom said it was "appalled" by the media reports.
"Allegations of tax evasion are entirely without merit," the company said in an unsigned statement.
"The company also wishes to clarify that it has not received any research grants which carry any restrictions on technology transfer - contrary to some media reports."
News Datacom develops and sells encryption systems mainly for pay television broadcasters, like Murdoch's SKY Television.

The News Datacom statement attributed leaks to the media about the investigation to "a continuing extortion campaign against the company by former employees who have been sued in the UK by NDC (the Israeli company's parent) for defrauding it of millions of dollars," it said.
